name: Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad
architects: A.C. Norman, R.A.J. Bidwell, A.B. Hubback
info: This iconic landmark was the grand administrative center for the British. Built with over 4 million bricks, its 41-meter clock tower houses a one-ton bell that first chimed for Queen Victoria's birthday in 1897 [cite: 834-842]. [cite_start]Look for the granite bollards by the porch—they were for tethering horses! [cite: 851]

quiz.q: What was the cost of the building in Straits Dollars?

ai_context:
This is perhaps the most famous landmark in Kuala Lumpur! [cite_start]It was the main Government Office for the British Colonial administration[cite: 836]. [cite_start]Built for **$198,000 Straits Dollars**, it was the largest building of its day, constructed with over **4 million bricks** [cite: 835, 839, 843][cite_start].

**Don't Miss:** The imposing **41-meter (140ft) clock tower** with its copper dome[cite: 840]. [cite_start]It houses a one-ton bell that first chimed for Queen Victoria's birthday in 1897 [cite: 841-842].

**Look For:** Near the main porch, you'll see the tops of **granite bollards**. [cite_start]These were originally used for tethering horses! [cite: 851] [cite_start]They look sunken because the road level today is much higher than it was in the 1890s[cite: 852].

**Fun Fact:** The clock tower is often nicknamed the **'Big Ben of Malaysia'** and was the centerpiece for the 1957 Merdeka (Independence) celebrations at the field opposite.

name: Old Post Office
info: Built for $100,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style building served as KL's General Post Office until 1984[cite: 856]. It was designed by A.B. [cite_start]Hubback to perfectly match its famous neighbor, the Sultan Abdul Samad Building, and features wide verandahs and elegant horse-shoe arches[cite: 858].
ai_context:
Designed by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback** to perfectly complement its famous neighbor (Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad), this Moghul-style structure was KL's General Post Office until 1984[cite: 856, 858]. [cite_start]It cost **$100,000 Straits Dollars** to build.

**Look For:** It showcases Hubback's signature style with its wide, arcaded verandahs and elegant **horse-shoe arches**[cite: 858]. [cite_start]The building is now used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture[cite: 855].

**Fun Fact:** It was strategically built next to the old KL railway station, allowing mail to be processed and sorted efficiently as soon as it arrived in the city.

name: Wisma Straits Trading & Loke Yew Building
architects: B.M. Iversen (Loke Yew), A.K. Moosden (Chow Kit)
info: This cluster of buildings tells the story of KL's commercial boom. [cite_start]The Loke Yew Building (1930s) is a famous Art Deco structure[cite: 872]. [cite_start]Next door, the Chow Kit & Co. building (1905) shows off a Neo-Renaissance style with Flemish pediments [cite: 876-877]. These represent the empires of tin tycoons like Loke Yew.

quiz.q: The Loke Yew Building is a 6-storey ___ style structure.

ai_context:
This cluster tells the story of KL's commercial boom. The 6-storey **Loke Yew Building** is a famous example of the **Art Deco** style (a 1920s-30s style known for geometric forms), designed by B.M. [cite_start]Iversen [cite: 872-873]. [cite_start]It once housed John Little & Co., one of the earliest trading houses [cite: 871][cite_start].

Next door is the **Chow Kit & Co. Building** (1904-1906) in a **Neo-Renaissance style**[cite: 876]. [cite_start]**Look For:** Its unique Flemish-style pediments (the triangular top of the building) [cite: 877][cite_start].

**Fun Fact:** The Loke Yew Building is named after **Loke Yew**, a business magnate and philanthropist who was one of the richest men in British Malaya and a director of the Straits Trading Company[cite: 870].

name: Masjid Jamek
info: Officially Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Samad, this is one of KL's oldest mosques[cite: 884]. [cite_start]It's built at the historic confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers—the very birthplace of Kuala Lumpur! [cite: 881] [cite_start]It sits on the site of an old Malay cemetery [cite: 885] [cite_start]and features distinctive red and white brick bands[cite: 890].

quiz.q: Masjid Jamek is located on the site of a Malay...

ai_context:
This is one of KL's oldest and most beautiful mosques, officially named Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Samad. It was designed by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback** and cost **$33,500 Straits Dollars**[cite: 884].

**Don't Miss:** Its location! [cite_start]It is built at the historic **confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers**, the very birthplace of Kuala Lumpur[cite: 881]. [cite_start]This spot is also where the city gets its name, 'muddy confluence'.

**Look For:** The distinctive **red and white brick bands**[cite: 890], a Moghul-inspired design. [cite_start]Inside, the flooring uses original **Doulton tiles** designed in the pattern of prayer mats [cite: 893][cite_start].

**Fun Fact:** It sits on the site of an old Malay **cemetery** [cite: 885] [cite_start]and served as KL's main mosque until the Masjid Negara (National Mosque) was opened in 1965[cite: 894].

name: Medan Pasar (Old Market Square)
info: This was the original town center established by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy, which once housed his market and gambling sheds[cite: 896]. [cite_start]The square is lined with ornate 1907 Neo-classical shophouses[cite: 900]. [cite_start]Its centerpiece is the Art Deco Clock Tower, built in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI[cite: 900].

quiz.q: The 1937 Clock Tower commemorates the coronation of King ___ ___.

ai_context:
This was the original town center! [cite_start]It was established by **Kapitan Yap Ah Loy** and was the site of his large market and gambling sheds[cite: 896]. [cite_start]The ornate, three-storey shophouses you see today are from 1907 in a Neo-classical style [cite: 899-900][cite_start].

**Look For:** The centerpiece is the **Art Deco Clock Tower**, built in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of **King George VI**[cite: 900]. It was designed by A.O. [cite_start]Coltman and features a classic Art Deco **'sunburst' motif** at its base [cite: 901][cite_start].

**Extra Tidbit:** A few years ago, Medan Pasar was transformed into a pedestrian-only plaza, making it a wonderful place to sit and admire the architecture[cite: 903].

name: Sze Ya Temple
info: As Kuala Lumpur's oldest traditional Chinese temple, its construction was funded by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy[cite: 927]. [cite_start]It is uniquely angled away from the road to align with Feng Shui principles[cite: 907]. [cite_start]It's dedicated to the deities Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, who are said to have guided the Kapitan to victory during the Selangor Civil War[cite: 927].

quiz.q: Who was the founder of the temple in 1864?

ai_context:
This is the **oldest traditional Chinese temple** in Kuala Lumpur, founded by **Kapitan Yap Ah Loy** in 1864[cite: 905, 927].

**Look For:** The temple is uniquely **angled away from the road**. This is not a mistake! [cite_start]It was deliberately built this way to align with **Feng Shui** principles[cite: 907].

**Don't Miss:** The temple is dedicated to the patron deities Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya. [cite_start]But to the left of the main altar, you can also find a **special altar dedicated to Yap Ah Loy himself**[cite: 928], honoring him as the founder.

**Fun Fact:** The deities, Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, are based on two real-life individuals who were loyal friends and captains to Yap Ah Loy during the Selangor Civil War.

name: The Triangle (Old Federal Stores)
info: This building is highly unusual because it spans an entire triangular block and has no 'five-foot way' (the covered walkway found on most shophouses)[cite: 935]. [cite_start]It was once occupied by the founders of Cycle & Carriage, who imported the first cars into Malaya[cite: 936].

quiz.q: The unique Old Federal Stores building has no '___-foot way'.

ai_context:
This building is highly unusual for two reasons. First, it spans an entire triangular block. [cite_start]Second, it has **no 'five-foot way'**[cite: 935]. [cite_start]A 'five-foot way' is the name for the covered walkway found on the ground floor of almost all shophouses in the area.

**Look For:** The whimsical **garlic-shaped finials** (ornaments) on its roof [cite: 935][cite_start].

**Fun Fact:** This building was called the Old Federal Stores and was occupied in 1905 by the founders of the **Cycle & Carriage** company, who were responsible for importing many of the first cars into Malaya[cite: 936].

name: Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng
info: A true step back in time. [cite_start]This traditional medicine shop was established over 30 years ago and still retains its original glass cabinets and fittings[cite: 917]. [cite_start]It's a living museum where you can purchase traditional herbs for everything from coughs to stress relief[cite: 919].

quiz.q: This shop was established over how many years ago?

ai_context:
A true step back in time! [cite_start]This traditional medicine shop was established over **30 years ago** and still **retains its original fixtures and fittings**, including the old glass cabinets[cite: 917]. It's a living museum where you can purchase traditional herbs.

**Here's a local tip:** Many visitors stop by these traditional shops to try a cup of herbal tea, which is often brewed daily and can be good for cooling the body on a hot day.

name: Oriental Building
info: An Art Deco masterpiece. [cite_start]When it was completed in 1932, this 5-storey, 85-foot structure was the tallest building in Kuala Lumpur[cite: 938]! Designed by A.O. [cite_start]Coltman on a triangular plot, it has a beautiful curved facade and originally housed Radio Malaya[cite: 923, 939].

quiz.q: In 1932, this was the tallest building in KL, at ___ feet high.

ai_context:
This is a stunning Art Deco masterpiece! [cite_start]When it was completed in 1932, this 5-storey structure was the **tallest building in Kuala Lumpur**, standing at **85 feet**[cite: 938].

It was designed by **A.O. [cite_start]Coltman** for the Oriental Life Assurance Ltd [cite: 922-923][cite_start].

**Look For:** It has a beautiful **curved facade** that addresses the triangular corner of the two streets[cite: 938]. [cite_start]It also originally housed **Radio Malaya**[cite: 939].

**Fun Fact:** It was considered extremely modern and was one of the first buildings in Malaya to feature a basement, which was used for storing bicycles.

name: Flower Garland Stalls
info: A vibrant and fragrant stop. [cite_start]Here, you can watch artisans skillfully weave traditional fresh flower garlands, which are used for religious offerings and celebrations[cite: 941]. You can even learn how to make one!

quiz.q: You can learn how to make a traditional flower ___.

ai_context:
A vibrant and fragrant stop near the Teochew Association building. [cite_start]Here, you can watch artisans skillfully weave traditional fresh flower **garlands**[cite: 941]. These garlands, often made of jasmine and marigolds, are used for religious offerings at temples and for celebrations like weddings.

**Here's a local tip:** The artisans are usually happy to show you their craft. [cite_start]You can **learn how to make a traditional flower garland** or simply buy some fresh flowers[cite: 941].

name: Masjid India
info: This area's first mosque was a simple timber hut from 1893[cite: 943]. [cite_start]The current Southern Indian-style structure opened in 1966 [cite: 948-949]. [cite_start]A unique feature is that prayer services here are conducted in both Arabic and **Tamil**[cite: 952]. [cite_start]The surrounding arcade is famous for its textiles and spices[cite: 953].

quiz.q: Prayer service is conducted in Arabic and ___.

ai_context:
This area's first mosque was a simple timber hut from 1893[cite: 943]. [cite_start]The current Southern Indian-style structure was opened in 1966 to hold 3,500 people [cite: 948][cite_start].

**Don't Miss:** A unique feature of this mosque is that prayer services are conducted in both Arabic and **Tamil** [cite: 952][cite_start], reflecting the area's strong South Indian Muslim heritage.

**Extra Tidbit:** The surrounding arcade, Jalan Masjid India, is a famous shopping paradise, renowned for its colorful textiles, saris, spices, and traditional medicines[cite: 953].

name: P.H. Hendry Royal Jewellers
info: This is Malaysia's oldest existing jewellers[cite: 955]. It was founded by P.H. [cite_start]Hendry from Sri Lanka, who was shipwrecked en route to Australia! [cite: 957] [cite_start]The family's craftsmanship was so renowned they were appointed Royal Jewellers to **3** different Sultans in the 1920s[cite: 963].

quiz.q: P.H. Hendry was appointed royal jewellers to how many Sultans?

ai_context:
This is **Malaysia's oldest existing jewellers**[cite: 955]!

**Amazing Story:** It was founded by P.H. Dineshamy (who later changed the name to Hendry) from Sri Lanka. [cite_start]He was **shipwrecked** while on his way to Australia, landed in Singapore, and eventually made his way to KL to start his business [cite: 957-959].

**Don't Miss:** The family's craftsmanship was so renowned they were appointed **Royal Jewellers to 3 different Sultans** (Selangor, Kelantan, and Negeri Sembilan) in the 1920s. [cite_start]The three coats of arms can still be seen on their business card [cite: 962-963].

name: Panggong Bandaraya (Old City Hall)
info: Built for $107,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style beauty by A.B. [cite_start]Hubback housed the Municipal Offices and KL's only theatre [cite: 968-970, 974]. [cite_start]After being heavily damaged by a major **fire** in the mid-1980s, it was beautifully restored[cite: 975]. [cite_start]It is now the venue for the musical *MUD: Our Story of Kuala Lumpur*[cite: 975].

quiz.q: The building was razed by ___ in the mid-1980s.

ai_context:
This Moghul-style beauty was designed by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback** and completed in 1904 [cite: 968-970]. [cite_start]It originally housed the Municipal Offices and, significantly, **KL's only theatre auditorium** [cite: 968, 974][cite_start].

**Look For:** It carries the same Moghul style as the Sultan Abdul Samad building, with intricate arches, domes, and a beautiful bay window [cite: 970-972][cite_start].

**Fun Fact:** The building was heavily damaged by a major **fire** in the mid-1980s[cite: 975]. [cite_start]It was beautifully restored and became the venue for the popular musical *MUD: Our Story of Kuala Lumpur*, which tells the story of the city's pioneers[cite: 975].

name: Dataran Merdeka
info: The historic cricket 'Padang' (field) where Malaysian independence was declared in 1957[cite: 1083]. [cite_start]It features a 100m tall flagpole (once the world's tallest) [cite: 1086] [cite_start]and a Victorian fountain imported from England in 1897 [cite: 1087-1088].
ai_context:
This is **Merdeka Square**, the historic cricket field known as the 'Padang'[cite: 1081]. [cite_start]This is where the Union Jack was lowered and the Malayan flag was raised at midnight on **August 31, 1957**, marking independence [cite: 1083][cite_start].

**Look For:** The **100-meter-tall flagpole** (one of the world's tallest) [cite: 1086] [cite_start]and the ornate **Victorian fountain**, which was imported from England and installed in 1897 [cite: 1087-1088][cite_start].

**Extra Tidbit:** The building on the west side of the field is the **Royal Selangor Club**, founded in 1884. It's affectionately nicknamed **"The Spotted Dog"**[cite: 1103, 1110].

name: National Textile Museum
info: Originally built as the FMS Railway Offices [cite: 1119][cite_start], this is a classic example of 'Blood and Bandage' brickwork (alternating red brick and white plaster)[cite: 1120]. Designed by A.B. Hubback, it now houses a fascinating collection of Malaysian textiles.
ai_context:
This stunning building, designed by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback**, was completed in 1905[cite: 1117]. [cite_start]It was originally built as the **FMS Railway Offices** [cite: 1119][cite_start].

**Look For:** It's a classic example of **'Blood and Bandage'** brickwork, which is the local name for the style of alternating red bricks and white plaster bands[cite: 1120].

**Extra Tidbit:** Today, as the National Textile Museum, it houses four main galleries, including the **'Ratna Kencana'** gallery, which showcases traditional Malaysian jewelry and accessories.

name: OCBC Building
info: A 1936 Art Deco gem by A.O. [cite_start]Coltman [cite: 1126-1127]. [cite_start]It was very modern for its time, featuring a basement bicycle garage[cite: 1129]! [cite_start]Look up to see the mosaic panel high on the building's facade, which features a Chinese Junk ship—the bank's original logo[cite: 1132].
ai_context:
This is another Art Deco masterpiece by **A.O. [cite_start]Coltman**, built in 1936 for the OCBC bank [cite: 1126-1127].

**Look For:** High on the building's facade, you can see a **mosaic panel featuring a Chinese Junk ship**. [cite_start]This was the bank's original logo[cite: 1132]!

**Fun Fact:** This building was extremely modern for its time. [cite_start]It was one of the first in KL to be **designed as 'earthquake-proof'** and included an innovative **basement bicycle garage** for employees[cite: 1129].

name: Central Market (Pasar Seni)
info: Built in 1936 as the city's wholesale wet market[cite: 1134]. [cite_start]It used special 'Calorex' glass to keep the interior cool, which was a high-tech solution before refrigeration was common [cite: 1137-1138]! [cite_start]In 1986, it was saved from demolition and converted into the award-winning arts and crafts market we see today[cite: 1135].
ai_context:
This building, now known as Pasar Seni, was constructed in 1936 as the city's main **wholesale wet market**[cite: 1134]. It was designed by architect T.Y. Lee.

**Don't Miss:** The building was high-tech for its time! [cite_start]It used special **'Calorex' glass** in its windows, which transmits daylight but blocks 80% of the sun's heat, keeping the market cool *without* needing refrigerators [cite: 1137-1138].

**Fun Fact:** In the 1980s, the building was scheduled for demolition. [cite_start]It was saved by the Malaysian Heritage Society and beautifully repurposed into the arts and crafts market it is today[cite: 1135].

name: Jalan Yap Ah Loy
info: A short street with huge history. [cite_start]This road originally led directly to the home of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy, one of KL's founders[cite: 1146]. [cite_start]It joins Jalan Hang Lekiu, which was formerly Klyne Street and one of the only paved streets in the early city [cite: 1146-1147].
ai_context:
This short street has huge historical significance. [cite_start]It originally led directly to the home of **Kapitan Yap Ah Loy** [cite: 1146][cite_start].

**Extra Tidbit:** It joins Jalan Hang Lekiu, which was formerly known as **Klyne Street**[cite: 1146]. [cite_start]It was named after the Klyne brothers, one of whom was a surveyor and the other ran a pharmacy, and it was one of the only paved streets in the city [cite: 1147-1149].

name: Lebuh Ampang
info: Historically the street of the Chettiars (South Indian money-lenders)[cite: 1154]. Look closely at No. 85—it features beautiful ceramic peacock tiles! [cite_start]The peacock is the symbol of Lord Muruga, the deity of the Chettiar caste [cite: 1155-1156].
ai_context:
This street is historically the heart of the **Chettiar** community, who were South Indian money-lenders[cite: 1154]. [cite_start]The area is still filled with Indian restaurants, spice stores, and sundry shops[cite: 1152].

**Look For:** At **building No. 85**, you can see beautiful **ceramic peacock tiles** on the facade. [cite_start]The peacock is the sacred vehicle of Lord Muruga, the main deity of the Chettiar caste [cite: 1155-1156].

**Fun Fact:** Because of its strong South Indian influence, this street and the adjoining Jalan Masjid India are often collectively known as Kuala Lumpur's **'Little India'**.

name: Jalan Melaka
info: A mix of old and new. [cite_start]This street is notable for the Bank Muamalat building, which was cleverly designed to look like a traditional Malay House, despite being a modern banking hall[cite: 1160].
ai_context:
Jalan Melaka is a mix of old and new. **Look For:** The **Bank Muamalat** building. [cite_start]Although it's a modern banking hall, its architecture was designed to look like a **traditional Malay House**[cite: 1160].

**Extra Tidbit:** This is one of the city's older streets, originally linking the main river trading post to the road leading out towards the Ampang tin mines.

name: Selangor Mansion & Malayan Mansion
info: Completed in 1964, these 8-storey blocks were an early and important experiment in mass public housing for the newly independent nation[cite: 1167]. [cite_start]They provided homes for 160 families and replaced the former squatters of Lorong Gombak[cite: 1164, 1166].
ai_context:
Completed in 1964 for **$2.5 million**, these 8-storey blocks were an early and important experiment in **mass public housing** for the newly independent nation[cite: 1165, 1167]. [cite_start]They provided 160 flats and replaced a former squatter settlement[cite: 1164, 1166].

**Fun Fact:** These buildings are a prominent local example of **Brutalist architecture**, a style known for its raw concrete, blocky forms, and functional design that was popular in the 1960s.

name: Wisma Yakin
info: Built in the 1970s, this tower was once the tallest in the area[cite: 1170]. [cite_start]It was developed by Malay entrepreneurs and remains the absolute best place in the city to buy traditional Malay attire like Baju Melayu and Songkok (traditional cap)[cite: 1170, 1172].
ai_context:
Built in the 1970s, Wisma Yakin was the **tallest building in the area** at the time[cite: 1170]. [cite_start]It was a landmark project developed by Malay entrepreneurs with support from PKNS (Selangor State Economic Development Corporation) [cite: 1170][cite_start].

**Here's a local tip:** It remains the **best place in all of KL** to buy traditional Malay attire like **Baju Melayu** (the traditional men's outfit) and **Songkok** (the black velvet cap)[cite: 1172]. [cite_start]The shop at No. 11 is run by an expert in the craft[cite: 1173].

name: Jalan Melayu
info: Known as 'Malay Street', this area was once filled with spice factories and bakeries[cite: 1175, 1178]. [cite_start]Look for the 100-year-old business selling 'Kain Pelekat' (sarongs) at No 3-5, run by the Kulasingam Chettiar family since 1895[cite: 1179].
ai_context:
Also known as **'Malay Street'**, this area was named for the Malay settlers who lived here and was the site of the original Malay school [cite: 1175-1176]. [cite_start]It used to be filled with spice factories and Indian bakeries[cite: 1178].

**Look For:** At **No. [cite_start]3-5**, you can find the Goodluck Trading Company, a business run by the Kulasingam Chettiar family that has been selling **'Kain Pelekat'** (traditional woven sarongs) since **1895**[cite: 1179]!

name: Batu Road (Jalan TAR)
info: Now Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, this was originally just a track leading to the tin mines at Batu Caves[cite: 1181]. [cite_start]The stunning block of shophouses here (built 1912-1915) features giant pilasters and decorative plaster garlands[cite: 1183, 1185].
ai_context:
Now called Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman (Jalan TAR), this was originally just a dirt track leading through swamps and estates to the tin mines at **Batu Caves**[cite: 1181].

**Look For:** The stunning block of three-storey shophouses here (built between 1912-1920) are beautiful examples of Neo-classical style. [cite_start]They feature **giant pilasters** (the large columns) and **decorative plaster garlands**[cite: 1183, 1185].

**Fun Fact:** This road became KL's premier shopping street in the mid-20th century, famous for its department stores like the Globe Silk Store.

name: Old Survey Office
info: Another A.B. [cite_start]Hubback masterpiece, this building features a dramatic 400ft (121.6m) long arcade [cite: 1188-1189]. [cite_start]Look for the twin 'Chatris' (domed pavilions) on the roof[cite: 1189]. It was built for $150,000 and housed the Survey Department, which was crucial for mapping Malaya.
ai_context:
This is another masterpiece by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback**, built between 1909-1910 for **$150,000 Straits Dollars** [cite: 1188][cite_start].

**Don't Miss:** Its most dramatic feature is the **400-foot-long arcade** (covered walkway) that runs the length of the building[cite: 1189].

**Look For:** Look up at the roof to see the twin **'Chatris'**. [cite_start]A 'Chatri' is a small, elevated, dome-shaped pavilion, a common feature in Indian-inspired architecture that Hubback loved to use[cite: 1189].

**Extra Tidbit:** It originally housed the Survey Department, a vital office for the British administration, responsible for creating the first detailed maps of Malaya's land and resources.

name: Old High Court
info: Costing $208,000, this 1915 building by A.B. [cite_start]Hubback replaced the original courts on the hill [cite: 1193-1194]. [cite_start]It features a grand inner courtyard and a public entrance that faces the river[cite: 1195]. [cite_start]It is currently awaiting restoration by Kraftangan Malaysia[cite: 1199].
ai_context:
This grand building, also by **A.B. [cite_start]Hubback**, was built between 1912-1915 to replace the original Supreme Courts [cite: 1193-1194]. It cost **$208,000 Straits Dollars**.

**Look For:** Unlike the other buildings, its main public entrance faces the river. [cite_start]It was designed around a **grand inner courtyard** with a double staircase leading to the upper floor [cite: 1195][cite_start].

**Current Status:** After the courts moved to a new complex, this building was used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture[cite: 1198]. [cite_start]It is currently vacant and awaiting a new life, with plans for it to be restored and used by **Kraftangan Malaysia** (the national craft organization)[cite: 1199].
